skill.name: polars
skill.description: Fast in-memory DataFrame library for datasets that fit in RAM. Use when pandas is too slow but data still fits in memory. Lazy evaluation, parallel execution, Apache Arrow backend. Best for 1-100GB datasets, ETL pipelines, faster pandas replacement. For larger-than-RAM data use dask or vaex.
skill.summary: Fast in-memory DataFrame library for datasets that fit in RAM. Use when pandas is too slow but data ...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing no executable code. All 684 static findings are false positives triggered by markdown documentation patterns. The skill teaches Polars DataFrame library usage through code examples in documentation files.

content.value_statement: Polars is a high-performance DataFrame library for large datasets. It offers lazy evaluation for query optimization, parallel execution, and an expression-based API. Use it to replace pandas for faster data processing when working with datasets between 1-100GB.
actual_capabilities: Create and manipulate DataFrames with expression-based API
Use lazy evaluation for query optimization and parallel execution
Filter, select, group, and aggregate data efficiently
Read and write CSV, Parquet, JSON, and cloud storage formats
Perform joins, pivots, and data reshaping operations
limitations: Dataset must fit in RAM (use dask or vaex for larger data)
No multi-index support (Polars uses integer positions only)
Python functions in expressions disable parallelization
Streaming mode required for data larger than available memory

use_cases.title: Replace pandas for speed
use_cases.description: Migrate existing pandas code to Polars for 2-10x faster execution on medium datasets

use_cases.title: Build efficient data pipelines
use_cases.description: Create optimized data transformation pipelines with lazy evaluation and predicate pushdown

use_cases.title: Process large CSV and Parquet files
use_cases.description: Read, filter, transform, and export large data files with minimal memory usage

prompt_templates.title: Basic DataFrame creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to create a Polars DataFrame with name, age, and city columns. Add examples of selecting columns, filtering rows where age is over 25, and adding a computed column.

prompt_templates.title: Lazy evaluation patterns
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain lazy vs eager evaluation in Polars. Show me how to use scan_csv, build a query plan with filter and select, and when to call collect().

prompt_templates.title: Group and aggregate
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to group data by city and department, compute mean salary and count, and use window functions with over() to add group statistics to each row.

prompt_templates.title: Cloud storage I/O
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to read Parquet files from S3, Azure, and GCS using environment variables for credentials. Include examples of writing output back to cloud storage.

output_examples.input: How do I filter rows and add computed columns in Polars?
output: Create DataFrame with pl.DataFrame() dictionary syntax

best_practices: Use lazy evaluation (scan_csv) for datasets over 100MB to enable query optimization
Filter and select columns early in the pipeline to reduce data processed
Stay within the expression API instead of using Python lambda functions for parallel execution
anti_patterns: Using read_csv instead of scan_csv for large files (loads all data immediately)
Applying filters after aggregations instead of early in the pipeline
Using map_elements with lambda functions when native expressions can achieve the same result

faq.question: How is Polars different from pandas?
faq.answer: Polars has no index, uses strict typing, supports lazy evaluation, and parallelizes operations by default.

faq.question: When should I use lazy mode?
faq.answer: Use lazy mode for datasets over 100MB, complex query pipelines, and when performance matters.

faq.question: What data sizes can Polars handle?
faq.answer: Polars works best for 1-100GB datasets that fit in RAM. Use streaming mode or dask for larger data.

faq.question: Does Polars support multi-index?
faq.answer: No, Polars uses integer row positions only. Consider adding an index column if needed.

faq.question: Can I use Polars with cloud storage?
faq.answer: Yes, Polars reads and writes to S3, Azure Blob Storage, GCS, and BigQuery directly.

faq.question: How do I migrate from pandas?
faq.answer: Replace df['col'] with df.select('col'), df[df['col'] > 10] with df.filter(), and df.assign() with df.with_columns().
